Growing under white(?) pine. Red oak further. Cap slimy. Glandular dots absent or very difficult to see. Context whitish to pale yellowish and not staining.

Yellow brown cap with reddish overlay, bright yellow tubes that blue instantly, depressed yellow orange pore surface that blues instantly then browns, white flesh in cap, smooth brown stem with yellow apex, stem flesh is white on upper two thirds and red on lower third, mild taste, with ponderosa pine, spruce and gambel oak. Same as obs 250095.

The odor of dried material for this obs and obs 250094 is bad. I’ve never smelled boiled urine, which is the smell described for this species, but I can imagine it would be close to what these smell like. Other characters fit too: the tendency of the cap to crack in hot weather, the depressed reddish pore surface that blues then browns, the smooth/misc. stem that is yellow at the apex, darker below and red at the base of the stem.
Definite smell of almond extract when cut

results.notes:
Fongarium: cKc0399
Date: 08.VIII.2015
Biotopes: pousse au sol, sous feuillus et conifères ;

Basidiome 20-50 mm de hauteur, 20-100 (120) mm Ø, globuleux à subglobuleux, parfois ellipsoïde, déprimé à maturité, souvent plissé ou même lobé sur les côtés et au-dessous, sessile ou relié par une touffe de cordons mycéliens blanchâtres agglomérant des débris, à péridium simple, dur, épais, 1-3 mm, craquelé-aréolé et avec grosse verrue centrale aplatie ou pyramidale plate, formant un motif en relief, avec ornementations disposées en rosette vers l’apex, ocre, brun jaunâtre à jaune doré, devenant rosâtre au froissement ou à la coupe, s’ouvrant au sommet par des fentes irrégulières lobées, non stellées ;
Glèbe blanche et longtemps ferme au début, puis gris violacé à noirâtre, souvent marbrée de blanchâtre, demeurant ferme, poudreuse à granuleuse à la fin, après l’ouverture du péridium, à odeur aigre ou agréable ;

Confirmé par Claude Kaufholtz-Couture

Fongarium: cKc0390
Date: 03.VIII.2015
Biotopes: pousse au sol, sablonneux, mousse ;

Basidiome 20-60 (80) mm Ø, subglobuleux à distinctement aplati ou pulviné au-dessus, sessile ou relié par un faisceau mycélien en pseudopied agglomérant des débris, à péridium épais, de 1-3 mm, tenace, lisse à finement écailleux puis craquelé-aréolé, surtout au-dessus, pâle, vite chamois, paille, jaune orangé brunâtre, brun rosâtre à brun ochracé, rougissant au froissement, s’ouvrant par un fente irrégulière ou cratère au sommet, en formant parfois des lobes ;
Glèbe longtemps blanche et très ferme au début, devenant rose rougeâtre à vineuse à la coupe, noir pourpré à noire, marbrée de blanchâtre, et poudreuse à maturité ;

Confirmé par Claude Kaufholtz-Couture

Fongarium: cKc0550
Date: 27.VIII.2016
Biotopes: pousse au sol de forêt mixtes ;

Macromorphologie
Chapeau convexe puis étalé-déprimé, sec, finement velouté, blanchâtre, jaunâtre ou brunâtre par endroits, 83 mm Ø ;
Lames adnées, étroites, avec lamellules, subespacées à espacées, crème jaunâtre, souvent avec gouttelettes crèmes jaunâtre ;
Pied égal à atténué vers la base, trapu, plein, sec, finement velouté, ferme, concolore au chapeau, 30 × 22 mm Ø ;
Chair ferme, blanchâtre-crème à jaunâtre ;
Latex blanc à la coupe, devenant crème jaunâtre ;
Odeur agréable ;
Latex très âcre (une gouttelette suffit pour brûler) ;
Réaction chimique:
KOH 10 %: chair devient orangé ;
Remarque: Le latex semble tacher les lames de brunâtre-rouille ;

Détermination provisoire par Claude Kaufholtz-Couture

Fongarium: cKc0544
Date: 18.VIII.2016
Biotopes: pousse au sol, sous conifères ;

Chapeau 50-150 mm de hauteur, 30-120 mm Ø, en entonnoir, à face interne ornée de grosses mèches ou d’écailles orange à orange rougeâtre sur fond pâle ;
Hyménophore formé de plis et de rides fourchus, décurrent, interveiné, crème ou beige ;
Pied 10-50 × 10-30 mm Ø, peu distinct, atténué vers la base, plein puis creux avec l’âge, sublisse, blanchâtre ou crème ;
Chair ferme, blanchâtre ;
Odeur et saveur odeur indistincte et saveur acidulée ;
Sporée ocre pâle ;

Confirmé par Claude Kaufholtz-Couture

Fongarium: cKc0540
Date: 18.VIII.2016
Biotopes: pousse au sol, sous bouleaux et conifères ;

Chapeau convexe à largement convexe, subétalé, sec, fibrilleux-méchuleux, grossièrement rugueux, crème, jaune paille à jaune brunâtre pâle, bleuissant fortement au froissement, à marge incurvée au début, unie, 125 mm Ø ;
Face poroïde blanchâtre, jaunissant à maturité, bleuissant immédiatement au froissement ;
Pores circulaires et petits, 1-2 par mm ;
Couche(s) de tubes concolore à la face poroïde, 5-10 mm de longueur ;
Pied subégal à renflé au milieu ou vers la base, cassant, sec, farci au début, devenant creux à maturité, subtomenteux-fibrilleux, concolore au chapeau, bleuissant au froissement, 85 × 32 mm Ø ;
Chair cassante, blanchâtre à jaune pâle, devenant rapidement bleu foncé à la coupe ;
Odeur et saveur odeur et saveur indistinctes ;
Sporée jaune pâle ;

Confirmé par Claude Kaufholtz-Couture

Fongarium: cKc0528
Date: 01.VIII.2016

Macromorphologie

Face poroïde rouge orangé à rouge vineux, bleuissant intensément au froissement ;
Pores circulaires et petits, 2 par mm ;
Couches de tubes jaune, 8-26 mm de longueur ;
Pied égal à subégal, plein, sec, finement velouté, orange rougeâtre sur fond jaune, devenant plus rouge avec l’âge, bleuissant au froissement, 85 × 20 mm Ø ;

Confirmé par Claude Kaufholtz-Couture

Fongarium: cKc0007
Date: 04.VIII.2012
Biotopes: pousse en touffes denses et volumineuses, sur racines et/ou souches enfouies de chêne rouge. Un bouquet peut contenir entre 45 et 70 spécimens, cespiteux ;

Macromorphologie
Chapeau 40-150 mm Ø, non détachable du pied, glabre au début, puis très finement fibrilleux, convexe, étalé-déprimé, légèrement en entonnoir, parfois à la marge enroulée, orange à roux, plus foncé au centre, se craquelant en vieillissant, et se pelant comme une écorce, laissant entrevoir les lames, cuticule séparable jusqu’à la moitié du chapeau lorsque jeune, et séparable jusqu’au ¼ lorsqu’il est à maturité, laissant voir une chair ferme, orangé pâle ;
Lames étroites, orangées, serrées, décurrentes, fourchues près du pied, lamellules, arête légèrement plus foncée ;
Pied 30-70 × 10-20 mm Ø., blanchâtre à grisâtre, orangé à concolore, plus pâle que le chapeau, plein, ferme, parfois légèrement excentré, fibreux, puis strié longitudinalement, finement radicant, qui à maturité, se fend horizontalement comme de petits anneaux [bracelets], laissant ainsi la possibilité de les détacher jusqu’à la base du pied, ou presque, d’où l’on peut observer un léger suintement du pied, cespiteux ;
Exhalaison agréable, légèrement d’agrume, orange ;
Saveur début fongique avec une finale finement raphanoïde ;
Sporée crème, jaune pâle à légèrement verdâtre ;
Réactions chimiques:
Chapeau: légèrement verdâtre avec le KOH 10 % ;
Lames: brunes à brunâtres avec le FeS04 après ± 5 minutes ;
Pied: légèrement verdâtre sur la chair avec le KOH 10 % et avec le NH4OH 10 % ;
Remarque: De fines gouttelettes orangées [collantes, visqueuses], comme exsudées, se fixent sur le chapeau et sur les lames, et tache les doigts ;

Micro
Basides piriformes à 2-4 stérigmates ;
Spores subglobuleuses à largement ellipsoïdes, lisses, à paroi mince, avec appendice hilaire, à contenu uniguttulé, hyalines à verdâtre dans le NaOH 2,5 , inactives dans le Melzer, cyanophiles
4,9 [5,3; 5,5] 5,9 × 4,4 [4,7; 4,8] 5,1 µm
Q = 1 [1,1; 1,2] 1,3; N = 50; C = 95
Me = 5,4 × 4,7 µm; Q moyen = 1,1
Cheilocystides fusiformes courbées, cylindriques, ramifiées à l’apex, irrégulières, et parfois diverticulées ;
Stipitipellis avec extrémités hyphales dans le revêtement caulinaire ;
Trame lamellaire parallèle à subparallèle ;
Boucles observées dans le pileipellis ;

Confirmé par Claude Kaufholtz-Couture

results.notes:
Fongarium: cKc0136
Date: 27.IX.2013
Biotopes: pousse souvent sur bois pourri, dans l’humus, la litière et les sphaignes ;

Macromorphologie
Ascome 20-70 mm de hauteur, formé d’un capitule fertile et d’un pied indistincts, clavé à lancéolé, noir brunâtre à noir ;
Capitule 10-30 mm de longueur, 30-50 mm Ø, occupant 1/3 de l’ascome total, spatulé, lancéolé, liguliforme à cylindrique, comprimé au centre ou irrégulièrement sillonné, apparaissant finement épineux (loupe), noir ;
Pied 20-60 × 4-6 mm Ø, égal à élargi aux deux bouts, droit ou flexueux, aplati, rarement un peu comprimé, lisse puis sillonné longitudinalement, densément velouté, apparaissant finement épineux (soies à la loupe), noir ;

Micro
Planche micrographique: cKc0136-0086
Spores 100x dans le NaCl, bacilliformes, légèrement atténuées aux bouts, entre trois et six septa, mais souvent à trois septa, grisâtres à brunâtres dans le NaCl, 45-85 × 6-7 µm ;
Asques 100x dans le R.C.Sds, claviformes, et légèrement atténués vers l’apex, à huit spores parallèles, 160-200 × 14-19 µm ;
Poils 40x dans le B.C.lactique, aciculées, brunes, > 150 µm de longueur, se projetant à environ 1/3-1/2 de leur longueur au-delà de l’hyménium ;
Poil 40x dans le R.C.Sds, dont l’apex est blanchâtre ;
Paraphyses 100x dans le R.C.Sds, filiformes, septées, élargies et courbées à l’apex ;

Confirmé par Claude Kaufholtz-Couture

Growing in white sand in forest of relatively pure loblolly pine, here coming up through the needle duff. Cap yellow with subtle reddish markings. Wide sterile margin, pores olivaceous quickly staining dark blue black, recessed at stipe. Context of cap and stipe quickly staining medium blue when cut, base of stem quickly turning carmine red. Taste mild, odor not distinctive. Suspected to be mycorrhizal with pine and grass. context grayish with iron salts, orange-brown with KOH, pale tan with Ammonia. No or very little reticulation at top of stipe, but some reticular ridges drop on stipe from recessed pores near stipe. Insect damage limited, staining brown at first.

results.notes:
Fongarium: cKc0406
Date: 14.VIII.2015
Biotopes: pousse au sol, sous pins, dans la mousse ;

Macromorphologie
Apothécie (2) 5-12 mm de hauteur, (30) 10-40 (50) mm Ø, légèrement à profondément cupuliforme, stipitée, densément pubescent à villeux vers le pourtour, à marge enroulée au début puis étalée, souvent avec pubescence blanchâtre à blanc grisâtre, unie, crénelée à lobée ou rarement avec côtes s’étalant jusque sur le quart inférieur ;
Hyménophore lisse, noir au frais et au sec ;
Face externe duveteuse à écailleuse, brun noirâtre à noire ;
Pied (2) 5-30 (40) x 5-8 mm, court, égal ou élargi vers la base, rond, légèrement comprimé à légèrement côtelé surtout à la base à la coupe, rarement fortement côtelé, plein, brun très foncé à noir vers l’apex, souvent blanc à gris pâle à la base, couvert d’un duvet gris-brun ;
Chair mince, blanchâtre ;
Odeur et saveur odeur et saveur indistinctes ;
Sporée blanche ;

Planche micrographique: cKc0406-0132
Collection étudiée sur matériel déshydraté ;
Micro
Asques cylindriques, operculés, octosporés, iodonégatifs, 225-250 × 12,2-17 µm Ø ;
Ascospores unisériées, largement ellipsoïdes à ellipsoïdes, lisses, à paroi mince à légèrement épaissie, à contenu uniguttulé, hyalines dans l’eau glycérinée 20 %, iodonégatives, non cyanophiles
(16,2) 16,6 – 18,1 (19,3) × (11,2) 11,3 – 12 (12,7) µm
Q = (1,4) 1,43 – 1,56 (1,6) ; N = 30
Me = 17,3 × 11,6 µm ; Qe = 1,5
(Piximètre: formule classique, ascospores mesurées dans l’eau glycérinée 20 %) ;
Paraphyses cylindriques avec apex claviformes, devient progressivement élargi à l’apex, hyalines dans l’eau glycérinée 10 %, ou brun, à contenu finement granuleux, 3,5-8,5 µm Ø ;
Éléments formant des pics sur la surface l’excipulum en formation de chaînes, cellules claviformes à cellules terminales subglobuleuses avec rétrécissement, septées, (12,9) 18,8 – 24,8 (27,6) × (7) 8,1 – 11,1 (12,2) µm en moyenne ;
Remarque: Ascospores finement rugueuses au microscope à balayage électronique, (Scanning electron microscope (SEM)) ;
Collections examinées: cKc0406 ; cKc0419 ;

Article:
- Abbott, Sean P. & Currah, R. S. The Helvellaceae: Systematic Revision and occurrence in Northern and Northwestern North America, Mycotaxon, vol. LXII, pp. 1-125, April-May, 1997, 125 p.

Site internet:

Confirmé par Claude Kaufholtz-Couture

Fongarium: cKc0514
Date: 09.VII.2016
Biotopes: pousse au pied de souche de conifère ;

Macromorphologie
Basidiome annuel, piléé, stipité sur le sol de racines ou parfois effusé-réfléchi à sessile sur la base d’arbres vivants, les billes ou souches ;
Chapeau jusqu’à 250 mm Ø, circulaire, irrégulièrement lobé, dimidié, tomenteux à hirsute, noduleux-bosselé, légèrement zoné, orangé au début, brun jaunâtre à maturité, brun rougeâtre foncé au sec, à marge jaune soufre à vert-jaune au frais, brun-rouge à noire avec l’âge ;
Face poroïde orangée au début, brun verdâtre et brun jaunâtre à brun rouille avec l’âge ;
Pores anguleux à labyrinthiques, 1-2 par mm, à dissépiments épais, puis lacérés ;
Couche(s) de tubes décurrente, distincte du contexte, verdâtre à brun rouille, jusqu’à 1,5 mm de longueur ;
Pied jusqu’à 50 mm Ø, centré à latéral, court et trapu, simple ou ramifié ;
Contexte mou-fibreux, azoné, brun jaunâtre au début, brun rouille foncé avec l’âge, jusqu’à 15 mm d’épaisseur ;
Sporée blanc jaunâtre ;
Réactions chimiques:
KOH 5 %: devient noir sur le chapeau et le contexte ; sur jeunes sujets, il passe au rouge vin avant de noircir ;

Confirmé par Claude Kaufholtz-Couture

Date: 28.VI.2012
Biotopes: pousse sur bois vivant ou mort de feuillus ;

Macromorphologie
Basidiome 5-20 mm de hauteur, 5-35 mm de largeur, pulviné à tronconique au début, puis irrégulièrement conique-discoïde, conchoïde-lobé, irrégulièrement lobé, foliacé, cérébriforme ou parfois auricularioïde, un peu dressé, courtement pédicellé, formant des amas irréguliers peu fusionnés jusqu’à 100 mm ou plus, à face supérieure rugueuse, typiquement avec minuscules plaques verruciformes ou projections dispersées et noirâtres, mate, à face infère hyméniale sublisse, un peu rugueuse-écailleuse, ondulée à ridulée-alvéolée, sans pustule, translucide, légèrement brillante, brun jaunâtre, brun fumée, ambrée, brun foncé, brun rougeâtre foncé, brun cannelle à brun pourpré, en film indistinct noir et cassant au sec, à marge légèrement épaissie et irrégulière, remarquablement plissée ;
Chair coriace-gélatineuse au début, gélatineuse-molle avec l’âge ;

Micro
Spores allantoïdes arquées, biguttulées, des conidies, des épibasides et des hypobasides ;

Two caespitose clusters of a total of 9 fruiting bodies growing under old white oaks, a young white pine and a cluster of young hemlocks.
Keyed out beautifully in NAB/BRB and matched the reported description. This is my first time encountering the species in the field. I am pretty sure I was guided to these mushooms by the spirit of the late Ernst Both. :-)

DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion:
Results:
A clean and contiguous TEF-1 sequence of 1115 bps has been obtained from this collection by Dr. Kudzma and uploaded to this post. The sequenced fragment of the gene starts from the first character (a “C”) immediately following the EF1-983F primer (edited out) and terminates in character #156 following the EFgr primer. There are 7 ambiguous bases present in this read: 4 x “Y” (C/T), 2 x “R” (A/G) and an “S” (C/G).
A BLASTn search of the whole sequence gave two high-scoring hits with Ernst Both’s accessions of Rubroboletus rhodosanguineus:
MG897426 = “R. rhodosanguineus voucher BOTH4263” = 1109/1115 = 99.5% similarity (6 ambiguities in MO250470)
KF030412 = “R. rhodosanguineus voucher 4252” = 1108/1115 = 99.6% similarity (7 ambiguities in MO250470)
Alignment of this sequence with the TEF-1 of Eva’s obs 284926 shows the 959 bps overlap to be 99.7% similar (3 ambiguities in MO250470).
Alignment with the TEF-1 of Dario’s obs 285495 shows the 1115 bps overlap to be 99.5% similar (6 ambiguities in MO250470).
Alignment of this sequence with the TEF-1 of Logan’s obs 294540 shows the 1071 bps overlap to be 99.25% similar (7 ambiguities in MO250470 and 1 in MO294450).
Alignment of this sequence with the TEF-1 of Logan’s obs 320146 shows the 1004 bps overlap to be 99.5% similar (5 ambiguities in MO250470).
Of course, a number of matching haplotypic combinations are common to all 7 organisms.

Comment:
The identity of this voucher is confirmed by TEF-1 sequencing. Even though this collection has the largest number of ambiguous positions in its sequence relative to those of the other 6 vouchers, some of the ambiguities present in this collection are shared. The raw similarity with the other 6 accessions is in the 99.25-99.7% range, but the pair-wise similarity is higher. TEF-1 easily distinguishes rhodosanguineus from other species of Rubroboletus (data as per the BLASTn results).
Uncertainty still remains regarding the identity and taxonomy of B. rubroflammeus A.H. Sm. & Thiers. Conspecificity between the two taxa cannot be completely ruled out in the absence of genetic data for comparison. Other than Smith & Thiers holotype, M. Kuo’s voucher is the only material that best resembles rubroflammeus : https://www.mushroomexpert.com/boletus_rubroflammeus.html.

results.notes:
Agaricus silvaticus Schaeff., Agaricaceae, Agaricales. (Bleeding Agaricus = Шампиньон лесной)
Cap: 5-12 cm semi-spherical or bell-shaped, then convex, broadly convex up to almost flattened; smooth and pale reddish-brown when young then pinkish-white with purplish-brown scales, then chocolate-white, light brown or dull pinkish-brown and indistinct concentric scaly when old; young cap bottom is covered with veil, later cap margin sometimes has hanging veil remnants. Young flesh is white with bright red bruising, old flesh pinkish-white weak purplish bruising.
Gills: free, very close, moderately broad then broad when old; color from pinkish-white, then light pink, brownish-pink up to purplish-brown when old.
Veil: partial veil white outside and pink inside (upper side), then leaving flaring up to pendant ring.
Stalk: 7-15cm long, white, sometimes pinkish-white, bruising bright red; 1.5-3cm thick, slightly enlarging down, rarely with indistinct basal bulb; old basal part has yellow cutting, middle of stalk often hollow with edging.
Edibility: good after boiling or preliminary dried.
Habitat: common kind, rare small groups scattered in pine-tree forest with rare deciduous trees.
Season: July – September.

Macromorphologie
Basidiome annuel, sessile, stipité, avec lien stipitiforme large ou en rosette jusqu’à 1 mètre carré ou plus, charnu-mou au début, fibreux-tenace avec l’âge, aqueux au frais, plutôt léger, crayeux-friable et cassant au sec ;
Chapeau jusqu’à 450 × 300 × 30 mm, incliné, semi-circulaire à dimidié, pétaloïde à flabelliforme, étalé, sec, finement velouté à densément feutré et laineux, puis glabre, plissé radialement et rugueux, non à légèrement zoné, orange saumon brillant au frais, jaune orangé à brunâtre pâle avec l’âge ou au sec, blanchâtre à la fin, à marge obtuse, ondulée, souvent lobée, stérile ou fertile au-dessous, orangé pâle, plus vive avec l’âge et au sec ;
Face poroïde jaune citron à jaune crème brillant au frais, se décolorant au froissement, brun sombre chez les vieux basidiomes, tan pâle au sec ;
Pores presque ronds au début, plus anguleux avec l’âge, 2-4 par mm, à dissépiments minces et entiers, vite lacérés ;
Couche(s) de tubes décurrente, jaune soufré au frais, chamois pâle au sec, distincte, 1-5 mm de longueur ;
Pied latéral, concolore au chapeau ;
Contexte ferme, cassant, vite coriace, juteux à succulent au frais, crayeux ou s’émiettant au sec, azoné, blanc à jaune pâle, jusqu’à 30 mm d’épaisseur, parfois plus épais près du pied ;
Odeur et saveur odeur et saveur agréables de noisettes ;
Sporée blanche à crème ;

Micro
Planche micrographique: cKc0188-0040
Spores elliptiques, ovoïdes à largement ovoïdes, lisses, à paroi mince, à contenu variable, hyalines dans le NaCl, inactives dans le Melzer
5,5-7 × 3,5-5 μm
Cystides absentes;
Système hyphale dimitique avec hyphes générative sans boucles;
Boucles absentes;
Remarques : La chair devient noire dans le rouge Congo SDS;

The cap colors are reddish-brown, except the extreme margin, which I think is somewhat unusual for B. bicolor. Also, the pileilellis appeas to be granulose and finely cracked. Other than that, it’s a dead ringer for B. bicolor. Some bluing of the pores and tubes, but the rich yellow context remains unchanged.

results.location_name: Durand Eastman County Park, Irondequoit, New York, USA

results.notes:
I’ve never seen so many Destroying Angels growing in a very small area, period. There were dozens of them around, including small buttons just peeking through the ground and they could be seen from far away because of their bright white color and the thin woods (large and widely separated oaks in grass). These could well be A. bisporigera. The KOH reaction (10% solution) was positive, but not as strong or fast as I’ve seen in some of the NJ material. Needless to say, I didn’t collect any of these deadly beauties. :-)
This particular area (the land circumscribed by Lake Shore Blvd and Horseshoe Rd) is favored by some “ethnics” (a term allegedly coined by a well known mycologist I never met) who regularly make visits in summer and early fall months to collect B. subvelutipes. When I visited the park last year for the first time, I encountered an Asian woman collecting a large crop of these boletes. When I naively tried to explain to her that she could be a belly ache from eating them, but she just smiled and walked away. I smiled back figuring she most certainly boils them first. There were a few buttons that popped up a day ago and I collected them for the NBC project (to be posted later). This is the spot where obs 217124 and obs 217125 were made last September.

Cortinarius varius (Schaeff.) Fr., Cortinariaceae, Agaricales. (Паутинник изменчивый или кирпично-коричневый клейкий)

Cap: 4-10cm wide when adult, convex, then broadly convex with indistinct or blunted knob, up to almost flat, minor slightly sunken and also with a knob, dull orange-brown or dull yellowish-brown (when very dry), margins curved in and often with reddish remnants of veil; smooth or glossy when dry or some slimy in wet weather. Flesh is whitish or pinkish-white when young up to yellowish or brownish when old.
Gills: attached and pinching out toward stalk, close to almost distant; moderately broad or broad with short intermediate gills, color from light lilac to dull pinkish-brownish-yellow up to red-brown.
Veil: partial veil hairy and whitish (when young) up to brownish-red.
Stalk: 8-16cm long often with several irregular rims of hairy scales and with a clear brown-red hairy ring (remnant of veil), 1-2cm thick, pinkish-white and yellowish-brown up to reddish-brown (when old and dry); hollow with aging.
Edibility: good after boiling.
Habitat: scattered small groups in wet places of pine-tree forest with aspen and birches.
July – August.

results.notes: Ash, Hickory woods with some Oak, and White Pine. I believe that this is the latest I have found these in Luzerne County in Northeastern Pa. Besides this, other species have produced fruitings much later than those which I have found in the past five years. The lack of sufficient summer rain is more than likely the cause of these late fruitings, as temperatures this year were similar to those of the past five years. Temperature drops in the last few days/week have prevented these from being larvae laden as evidenced by the fact that of approximately 30-40 mushrooms, only two had larval holes/maggots present. Ya gotta love it?

results.notes:
Finally got to make a proper description, as well as in studio photos and a herbarium collection of a Suillellus species I found last year for the first time. Posted it on Facebook at the time, where Machiel Noordeloos, Geoffrey Kibby, Davide Puddu and Michael Loizides mentioned the collection might be Suillellus mendax, rather than Suillellus luridus, based on the incomplete and concolourous reticulation on the stipe and the very velutinose pileus when young. Here are the links to the posts in “Paddestoelen Groep Nederland” and “British Mycological Society”:

PGN
https://www.facebook.com/...

BMS
https://www.facebook.com/...

Description:

Pileus: 80 × 24mm (max. 180mm); convex at first, nearly flattened when expanded at maturity; first very velutinose, later bald and somewhat greasy; olivaceous in the center, then an orangy red band, finally olive yellow at the outmost margin, later entirely sordid olive yellow, sometimes with red hues; slow blueing after pressing with thumb and scratching.

Pores and tubes: Small, irregular, round; red, but with yellow zone around the pileal margin, sometimes orangy red or entirely yellow with slight red hues, one of last years specimens even had entirely greenish yellow pores (Beeckman, 2015); rapid blueing after bruising. Red with a lighter band along the pileal margin under the tube layer; slow blueing after removal of the tubes.

Spore colour: olivaceous

Stipe: 90 × 25 (37)mm (max. 180mm); central; club-shaped, irregular, often slightly bent; covered with more or less visible reticulum, especially at the apex fine-grained, at 1/4-1/3 coarser, from middle downwards often merely as longitudinal ribs; some specimens only had fine-grained reticulation at the apex, but a smooth stipe further down; reticulum concolourous with background or red like the pores (Beeckman, 2015); this particular specimen has a clear reticulum that is built up of fine dots/lines, especially at the apex, this has only become darker after picking; warm yellow stipe with concolourous to orangy red reticulum, sometimes red at the apex, further yellow, sometimes yellow at the apex with sordid red with beetred strikes (Beeckman, 2015); bruising fairly quick; remarkable are the thick rhizoids at the base of the stipe.

Context: First pale yellow, later white with yellowish tinge; changes to blue rapidly after cross-section, indigo in the pileal context, especially directly above the tubes, from the apex towards the stipe and in the stipe more of a greenish blueing; after one hour the blue almost gone, weakened, duller; alas, the base of the stipe was attacked by a secundary fungus, hence the colour in the base was merely brown because of the rot; very firm; pileipellis thick and clearly visible. Last years specimen: “The trama is remarkably tricoloured (yellow in the pileus, vinaceous in the stipe and vinaceous with deep blue in the, near indigo, in the stipe base) and changes into a beautiful deep ink blue colour directly after cross section” (Beeckman, 2015). No reaction with ammonia, dingy orange with KOH 3%.

Smell/taste: Weak truffle-ish/bolete-ish smell, taste pleasant but not strong.

Ecology: Terrestrial on relatively poor sandy soil with humus top-layer, associated with Fagus, Acer, Prunus serotina, Taxus and one specimen found lignicolous on Fagus stump. I have found Tricholoma scalpturatum at same spot each year as well.

Description (transcribed from short-hand field notes, with additional details inferred from photographs):

Pileus: Up to 14 cm (5.5”) wide at maturity, ¾ spherical at first, then hemispherical and finally broadly plano-convex; margin incurved at first, becoming de-curved, typically uneven and wavy all around or at least partially, with a prominent, curved band of sterile tissue present at first but generally disappearing in age; pellicle dry, faintly tomentose to minutely scruffy on the disk and almost smooth toward the margin at first, becoming uniformly smooth, bald and minutely rimose-areolate toward the periphery at maturity, covered with appressed, short, dark and interwoven fibrils and tiny scruffy tufts when young and fresh (the fibrils generally oriented radially from the disk center, taking on the appearance of being merely “painted” in the two older basidiomes), rich chamoisse to pinkish cocoa brown when young, becoming lighter in age on the disk and turning yellowish-brown toward the periphery, not discoloring in any way when touched or bruised; context dense and firm when young and less so in age, light to medium lemon yellow immediately above the tubes and more or less homogeneously paler yellow above when young, becoming faintly yellow maturity, not changing color at all when exposed to air, with light brownish-burgundy discoloration around larval tunnels; odor not distinct to faintly pleasant and somewhat fungal; taste mild at first, with a sour/lemony note perceived in a few seconds, and then becoming mild to non-distinct again (tasting caused a minor and reversible ulceration of the tip of the tongue).
Hymenophore: pore surface medium honey yellow to dingy egg-yolk yellow at first, becoming rich butter yellow and finally greenish mustard yellow at maturity, not bluing when touched or bruised, but the ground color merely intensifying upon injury, uniformly smooth when immature and prominently bumpy/pitted and uneven in age; pores closed and shut when young, circular to oval and 1-2 per mm at maturity; tubes 1 mm deep when very young and up to 17 mm deep at maturity, more or less concolorous with the pore surface, not bluing or discoloring when cut or exposed to air.
Stipe: Up to 10 cm (~4”) long; up to 1.8 cm (0.71”) wide at apex, up to 2.2 cm (0.87”) wide in the middle, and up to 3.2 cm (1.26”) wide at base [these dimensions correspond to the stipe of the largest immature plant, as it’s actually longer and thicker than that of the oldest specimen], oval-shaped in cross-section in all specimens, clavate to subclavate to almost equal, with a somewhat bulbous base, L-shaped to slightly bent to shallowly S-shaped to almost straight; surface uniformly pale/dull lemon yellow, with a brighter, richer yellow apex and with the base/bulb covered with a whitish bloom at first, gradually and uniformly assuming a light pinkish-brown or light vinaceous-brown coloration from the base all the way up to the apex in age, with a few random darker vinaceous-burgundy stains/areas when young, not bluing when handled or injured, prominently but not coarsely reticulated from the apex down to at least mid-length; reticulation somewhat raised, mesh small and very densely weaved in the apex, becoming wider-meshed and progressively elongated below, gradually changing over to a network of raised longitudinal ridges and then trailing off to a smooth surface toward the base, generally concolorous with the background color or slightly darker (especially after being handled); context generally whitish to grayish in the cortex, increasingly pale grayish-brown toward the base and in the bulb, with a continuous and narrow (2-3 mm) light to medium lemon-yellow band just below the stipe surface stretching from the juncture with the cap down to ⅔ of length, not bluing when exposed to air, firm and dense most specimens and more spongy-fibrous in the youngest one.
Spore print color: Light greenish olive.
Macrochemical tests: KOH = medium brown quickly changing to rusty orange-brown on pellicle; dark honey yellow-brown on cap context; pale orange on stipe context. NH3 (aq.) = rusty orange-brown on pellicle (similar to KOH reaction), flashing instantly with a wide vinaceous-purple halo around the droplet due to the ammonia vapors; pale yellow to pale greenish mustard yellow on cap context; pale orange on stipe context (similar to KOH reaction); FeSO4 = instantly grayish olive-green on pellicle; same but lighter on cap context; faint greenish-olive on stipe context.
Microscopic features: Mounted in Melzer’s, [40/1/1]; L x W = (10.1-) 10.5-12.8 (-13.3) x 3.5-4.0 (-4.3) μm; L’ x W’ = 11.4 × 3.7 μm; Q = (2.75-) 2.81-3.41 (-3.50); Q’ = 3.07; not amyloid, not dextrinoid, light buff to light straw, inequilateral, fusiform in face-view and subfusiform in lateral-view, smooth and thin-walled, cylindrical to bacilliform based on the Q-ratio range.
Fruiting: A single post-mature specimen growing in a few yards away from a group of 3 immature specimens in leaf litter in a stand of mostly young and old oaks mixed in with other young hardwood trees next to the South Rim Trail. The woods on the southern side of the gorge circumscribed by the trail and paved Gorge Road range from pure hemlock stands (the trailhead section), to a mixed hemlock-hardwood forest to extensive areas of thin, exclusively deciduous woodlands. No hemlocks or other conifers were observed in the vicinity of the collection location.
Comments: The post-mature fruiting body was discovered first. Originally, it gave a strong impression of an old B. separans, owing to the coloration of the cap and stipe, and was almost discarded. Searching the immediate area led to the detection of the three young specimens at the base on an oak tree. The connection between the two collections was not immediately recognized, despite their proximity, as the immature fruiting bodies looked nothing like the aged one, till the specimens were examined more closely. The identical chemicals tests (on the pellicle) helped confirm both collections are very likely to be the same taxon.

Sequencing Results and Discussion (first posted Jan-2017; last updated 30-Nov-20):
> A clean and contiguous nrLSU sequence of the first 1441 bps has been obtained for this material and uploaded to this observation.
A GenBank BLASTn of the first 978 bases (the most commonly sequenced region of LSU) returned a hit list where the first 32 hits (97-99% identity) were all members of Butyriboletus. Interestingly, the top two hits were R. Chapman’s Butyriboletus pulchriceps vouchers (867/876 = 99.0% similarity, no gaps; 888/898 = 98.9% similarity, 1 gap).
Boletus pulchriceps has recently been transferred to Butyriboletus together with two other North American taxa, Caloboletus peckii and Boletus roseopurpureus, by Zhao et al. (2015) based on molecular sequencing of relevant vouchers. I have already expressed my skepticism with regard to the transfer of C. peckii to Butyriboletus in light of the evidence from obs 246697, which I think represents Peck’s Bolete, and more evidence has emerged to say with certainty that But. peckii is a misnomer (vide infra).
A BLASTn-500 of the LSU sequence of Neoboletus subvelutipes was used to generate a phylogenetic tree of Butyriboletus (Fig. 1). It shows the position of But. taughannockensis deep inside the clade. As expected, But. pulchriceps is the sister taxon. Note that “outlier Butter Boletes” with red pores, But. frostii and But. floridanus, were also included in the tree and didn’t clade together with the mainstream Butter Boletes.
> A clean and contiguous full length nrITS sequence of 673 bps was also procured for this material. Apparently, there was a non-specificity problem that precluded obtaining a contiguous end-to-end read from either direction. Hence, the present sequence is the merger of forward and reverse reads “stitched” at a problematic homopolymeric region (the “deca-T” motif).
The nrITS sequence was subjected to a BLAST GB database search. After analyzing the alignments, the unusual “deca-T” motif present in the middle of the sequence read of MO250839 (a string of 10 consecutive thymines) was identified as a problematic region, responsible for some of the observed deletions and insertions seen in the GB sequences. Still, notwithstanding the lower GB identity scores stemming for this problem, the BLAST list of the 100 top-scoring hits was exclusively comprised of members of Butyriboletus. Examination of the GB data revealed that the poly-T motif (usually 5 or 6 T’s in most Butter Boletes and as many as 9 consecutive T’s in But. pulchriceps, acccession #KT002604) appears to be a defining genetic feature seen in Butyriboletus.

Conclusions: MO250839 has all the major phenotypic hallmarks of a Butter Bolete. The nrLSU and nrITS sequencing data are also in good agreement with this proposal. The combination of morphological traits and molecular data both indicate that MO250839 is a novel species belonging in Butyriboletus. The closest genetic relative appears to be Butyriboletus pulchriceps. In light of the above information, I propose Butyriboletus taughannockensis Safonov, sp. nov. for this taxon. This name has been registered with Index Fungorum.
An IF Nomeclatural Novelty e-publication has just been published (1-18-17): http://www.indexfungorum.org/....

Lyophyllum connatum, Tricholomataceae, Agaricales. (Лиофиллум сросшийся).
Cap: 5-10cm wide, whitish or light gray up to very pale brownish-grey (irregular coloured because covered with whitish soapy or silky “powder”), smooth; convex or “square head” (young) up to broadly convex, sometimes with indistinct wide knob or depression and irregular wavy margins; often overlapped, sometimes inter grow each other. Flesh is white; odour is unpleasant as bad soap or dichlorvos type.
Gills: attached with pinching out toward stalk, narrow or moderately broad up to broad, whitish or cream-white up to yellowish-white when old.
Stalk: 6-10cm long, 1.0-2.5cm thick and usually enlarged toward base, white and silky up to yellowish-white and indistinct fibrous. They accreted together by three or more.
Habitat: small, minor big crowded clusters in pine-tree forest with some birches and aspen.
Edibility: not edible.
Season: July-August.

Craterellus lutescens Fr. (Fr.) = Лисичка желтеющая ворончатая
Cap: 2-4 cm wide when adult, convex with sunken funnel-shaped centre and margin curved down, then almost flat, sometimes with decurved up crimped wavy margin, narrow and wrinkled funnel into stalk; colour is orange-brown up to reddish-brown or brown. Cap surface is fine velvety or smooth and some bumpy or radial wrinkled; flesh is thin yellowish or pinkish-white. Fertile surface looks as branched tube-shaped gills: narrow thick-edged ridges forked and rare cross-veined, distant and descending stalk, yellowish or pinkish-white.
Stalk: 4-7cm long, 0.5-1cm thick and hollow, usually wrinkled along (double tube) enlarged up to a cap and change into a cap often dividing into 3-5 main branches or tube-shaped ridges; orange-yellow or yellow up to brownish-yellow when old.
Edibility: edible.
Habitat: rare kind,small group or crowded clusters scattered in wet places of pine-tree forest with rare birches.
July – September.

results.notes:
On a bedrock outcrop, probably shale, on an exposed ridge in full sun, in a semi-arid grassland setting.

Thallus endolithic. Large flat apothecia, lecideine, black, epruinose, with slightly raised grey rim when young. Exciple without algae. Hymenium hyaline, epihymenium black, with greenish tinge, hypothecium brownish. K/I blueish on paraphyses.
Growing on the ground in the near vicinity of White Oaks.

Fruiting in large rosettes on ground surrounding a dead tree. Mature rosettes about 30 cm across. Did not bruise immediately, however after about a half hour, dark edges and areas appeared (photo). Smelled pleasant.
Growing on the ground in grass in an area of White Oaks.

Disintegrating serpentine rock outcropping in a semi-arid grassland setting.

Thalus brown, areolate, without lobes or prothallus, but with thick flaky off-white pruina. Apothecia lecanorine, flat, with black disk and raised margin, uncommon. Exciple with green algae, and a thin hyaline thalline exciple averaging about 10µm wide. Hymenium very short, I-, IKI+blue, Epihymenium red-brown, K-. Paraphyses segmented but not moniliform that I could tell.

Asci clavate, hyaline, appearing I-, not sure how many ascospores. Spores long and narrowly ellipsoid, not generally falcate (sickle-shaped), sometimes deformed long. Measurements of a couple spores: 19.6×3.6µm, 13×3µm, 16.7×3.6µm

The best I could do on this one is a genus called Harpidium. The red epihymenium is distinctive, and is consistent with this genus, as are other features. Few species descriptions out there though.
